content: The Act titled "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" mandates electronic submission of biographical information by visa waiver participants. The Secretary of Homeland Security must establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The electronic system required for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information must provide an electronic response within 30 minutes regarding their eligibility to enter the US as a nonimmigrant visitor. The electronic system for visa waiver program participants must provide an electronic response within 30 minutes regarding their eligibility to enter the US as a nonimmigrant visitor, including carrier obligations. The system under section 101(a)(15)(B) of the Immigration and Nationality Act requires carriers to electronically inquire about an alien passenger's eligibility for admission without a visa, with responses provided in 90 seconds or less. The system described in this section requires carriers to electronically inquire about an alien passenger's eligibility for admission without a visa, with responses provided in 90 seconds or less. The system shall be deployed soon after the enactment of this Act, and a fee will be charged to eligible aliens to ensure cost recovery. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of equipment and software at all ports of entry into the United States for biometric comparison and authentication of visas and travel documents issued to aliens by October 26, 2004. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry for biometric comparison and authentication of visas and travel documents issued to aliens by October 26, 2005. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires technology standard implementation by October 26, 2005. Additionally, a limited good faith waiver is provided. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows for limited good faith waivers for countries making progress in passport issuance deadlines. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows for up to 2 extensions for countries and their nationals to meet passport issuance deadlines if substantial progress is being made. Each extension can be up to 6 months. The Secretary of Homeland Security considers various factors to determine progress. The Act allows for up to 2 extensions for countries to meet passport issuance deadlines, each not exceeding 6 months. The Secretary of Homeland Security considers factors like good faith efforts by the country to comply with requirements by a specific date. The Secretary of State certifies whether a country has made good faith efforts to meet passport issuance deadlines and has a program in place to comply with requirements by specific dates. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, must issue an initial report by October 26, 2005, on whether a country has started a pilot program to issue passports meeting requirements before March 26, 2006. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, will issue an initial report by October 26, 2005, on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements before March 26, 2006. A final report will be issued by April 25, 2006. The Secretary of Homeland Security, with the Secretary of State, will issue a final report by April 25, 2006, on countries' progress in meeting passport requirements. SEC. 6.
